div.head: NOTICE
div.p: During the absence in Europe of Mr. ROWLAND SNELLING-, Editor and Manager of the "Egyp- tian Gazette," all cheques and re- ceipts will be signed by Mr. G. I. SWANSON, acting Editor and Ma- nager, and countersigned by Mr. A. MARA VELU, Cashier. 30783-15

div.head: Police Budget.
div.p: 7 thefts, 11 misdeameanors and 67 minor offences took place in Cairo and its suburbs yesterday.

div.head: The Streets of Cairo
div.p: The Tanzina Service has asked for credit of LE 4,200 for the repair of the roads in Old Cairo

div.head: Seizure of Haslah
div.p: Yesterday morning, the Coastguard patrol seized 540 kilos of hashish which they discovered west of Agami.

div.head: S.P.C.A
div.p: The report that the Society of the prevention of Cruelty to Animals had engaged four new inpsectors is incorrect.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: Les Cloches de Corneville, the ever popular three act operetta of Planquetta is to be staged at the Alhambra Theatre tonight and will doubtless attract a large house.

div.head: New Quarantine Station
div.p: The Ministry of Interior has approved the credit of $9,000 to the Sanitary Department for the building of a new quaratine station at Tor.

div.head: Gubonic Plague
div.p: Two deaths from the bubonic plague outside of hospial at Alexandria and 1 death at Damanhour were the only cases reported during the past 24 hours 15 patients still remain under treatment.

div.head: The Missing Camel Corps
div.p: The Sudan Government has sent a fresh expedition of 30 men and 50 camels to search for the camel corps lost in the BirNatron desert. The expedition is expected to return about the middle of the month.

div.head: Cattle Plague
div.p: During the week ending the 5th instant, 536 births and 771 deaths, fof which 20 were Europeans, were registered in Cairo and its surburbs. 5883 deaths were children under 5 years of age. Dyptheria was the cause of 2 of the deaths, typhus 12, typhoid 5, measles 37 and erysipelas 1.

div.head: Cairo's Burglar
div.p: A burglary took place at the house of a money changer, named Naguib El Asmar, at Mansourah yesterdy. Some L.E. 4,000 in cash besides a quantity of jewelry, were stolen. Notices have been issued to all the principal towns in Egypt, giving a description of the supposed thieves.

div.head: The Cunard Line.
div.p: The new Cunarder "Lusitania" the largest passenger steamer in the world, will make her first trip from Liverpool to New York on the 7th September, the sailing day of the "Lucania". The "Lusitania" is driven by turbines and is a sister ship to the "Mauritannia" now completing on the Tyne. These gigantic vessels are 790 feet long with breadth of 88 feet, a depth of 60 feet, a draught of 37 feet, and a tonnage of over 33,000 tons. The "Lusitania" will then cross from Liveroppl regularly as per itinerary on the 5th October, 2nd and 30th November and so on.

div.head: St.James Restaurant.
div.p: It is generally known as the St. James bar and restaraunt is shortly to be transferred to new premises in the Sharia Boulae. The new premises are all that can be desired and are most commodious. The improvements on the old premises are very considerable and the care manifested in the sanitary arrangements and kitchen will appeal to many who have observed certains shortcomings in these aspects. As regards the remainder of the establishment, the improvements are most appreciable and when the Cairo public are invited on the 15th of this month to enjoy the hospitality of the host, Mr. Philip Marburg, on the occasion of the opening ceremony, they will be surprised at the excellence of the arrangments, not the least of which is in the practical and useful arrangements of the wine cellars, which are well stocked, as befits an establishment conducted by an ex-employee of Cairo's premier hostelry.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S "Eastern Prince" left Antwerp on the 7th inst. and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 23rd inst.

div.head: MEDITTERANEAN COMMAND. DUKE OF CONNAUGHT APPOINTED
div.p: LONDON, August 8. HODSK OF COMMONS. - Mr. Haldane an- nounced the Duke of Connaught's appointment as Field-Marshal, Commander-in-Chief, and High Commissioner for the Mediterranean. Tho force under His Highness will comprise the garrisons of Gibraltar and Malta, the detachment at Croto and Cyprus, and the British troops in Egypt and the Sudan. Local military administrations will continue as at present. His Highness devoting himself to inspection, questions of training, strategy, and defence. ' (Ueuter

div.head: TRADE OF ALGERIA
div.p: It may interest some of your readers in Egypt to hear some details of the very fertile French colony of Algeria. The chief product of the country is wine, large quantities being exported to France. In 1906, 34,985,934 gallons went to Bordeaux. There the Algerian wine is mixed and blended with inferior French wines and pnt on the market as a cheap olarot. In fact tho Algerian wine alone is very palatable, roughish as all young wines are ; but the blending at Bordeaux becomes necessary, as a great prejudice exists against Algerian wine. Algeria being an entirely agricultural coun- try, like Egypt, tho French ljave done all in theii power to improve agricultural methods. Outside Algiers there is a very fine agricultural college with experimental gardens attached. Here during the last six months they have been experimenting with different cotton seeds both Egyptian and American, and, as far as can be judged, Mit-Affifi has given by far' the liest results. As to the chances of Algeria becoming a cotton producing country, the French ure sanguine, but on the other hand there are two distinctive negative (actors - first, inadequate water supply, secondly an extremely cold winter, necessitating a very late sowing. Cotton in a wild state is still to lie found near Bizerta in Tunisia, 'where the Arabs use it for blending with wool ; this wild plant extends right up to the west coast pf Morocco. Presumably the west coast of Morocco wquld make a better growing land for cotton, as tho climate is milder and river water is abundant. One ol the most interesting, though perhaps least known, industries of Algeria Is the produc- tion of vegetablefTbrefcrin vegele). Thisfibreis made from the dwarf palm (Chamerops humilis) which grows in large quantities along tho coast df Algeria. A few years ago this plant was looked upon as a useless weed, now it has been found to contain a most useful fibre and is largely sought after. This fibre is an excellent substitute for horse hair and is ingreat demand among upholsterers, mattress makers, harness makers ami carriage builders on the Continent for the cheaper class of goods. It is very much cheai>cr than horse hair and in many cases re- places it with advantage, especially as it is not affected or destroyed By insects. Factories for the production of this fibre liave been set up in many parts of Algeria, giving in each case employment to hundreds of Arabs, so much so that they have.a saying that "the palm was made to give bread to the poor." Whole families, men, women, and children, may be seen cutting the palm leaves making them into bundles, and carrying them sometimes many miles to the factory. In the factories the leaves are passed through a shredding machine, the fibre afterwards being spread out to dry, after which it is spun into ropes and baled ready forexport. Theropesare made in variousqualities according to the thickness of the rope and the fineness of the fibre, the prices varying from £4.15 to £6 a ton, quay Algiers. Germany and Austria are the principal buyers of this cordage, and it is utilised by the German War Office, being an article which from sani- tary, economical and general utility points of view is suitable for barrack and hospital bedding. A certain amount is said to be shipped to Egypt, where there are so many ocheap upholsterers, but there is iio regular ser- of steamships between Algiers and Alexandria. Likewise the French liave introduced the soap tree (sapindus utilis). It appears to be a hybrid, and has characteristics quite different from any of the known species of India and Chinn. In 'the berries of this tree one finds a large amount of saponaceous matter-about 30%. A good deal of the fruit is employed in its natural state, and many chemists produce specialities from it such as snponine, an excellent ' washing jiowder, and sapindine, a hair wash. , Among the. numerous other products can be mentioned cereals olives (for oil both crude and refined), fruits, vegetables, Esparta graas and various essences. A great mineral wealth has also been found, and is being slowly (owing to the want of capital) developed. W. A.

div.head: DEATH AT A MEETING
div.p: On Wednesday evening the annual general meeting of the Israelite Benevolent Society "Ahemla" was held under the acting presidency of M. Samuel Camhi.^vho opened the meeting with a short address, and at the close of which, feeling ill, he retired into au adjouring room, leaving the "ecretary to conduct the business. During the course of the re-election of M. Camhi as president, the sad news was brought that he had suocumbed to an attack df apoplexy. The meeting was immediately cob eluded.

div.head:
EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT
THE SPECIAL TRIBUNAL
div.p: Mr. MaoNeill (Donegal S.) asked the Secre- tary of State for Foreign Affaire whether, in viow ol the undertaking given by him and Lord Cromer, at various dates subsequent to the Denishwai executions, that tho decree of 1895 relative to offences against the army of occupation would bo enporaeded by another decree, he was in a position to state the time when such decree will bo promulgated ; and, if not, whether he could acoount for the delay in giving effect to the decision announced a year ago. Sir E. Grey.-Before Lord Cromer's depar- ture from Egypt it lutd already been found that the practical difficulties in the way of of reforming the Special Tribunal were very great, and it was therefore proposed temporarily to rely upon the ordinary law Courts of Egypt. In the meanwhile, there is no necessity to abrogate the degree of 1896, as the Special Tribunal can only be convoked on the applica- tion of his Majesty's Agent and Consul-General, who has been instructed not to take this step without previous reference to his Majesty's Government. Mr. MaoNeill asked if ho was to understand that the undertaking givon by the right hon. gentleman had not been fulfilled and that there was no intention of fulfilling it Sir E. Grey.-Tho Special Tribunal is not now in"xistence, and so long as it is not in. existence the decree cannot be promulgated. Mr. MacNoill asked could not the right hon. gentleman call it into oxistence by a stroke of the pen. Sir K. Grey.-Tho undertaking I gave was that the tribunal should be called into exis- tence when the reforms were introduced. KHEDIVIAL LAW SCHOOL. Mr. MacNeill asked whether the appoint ment of an Englishman to preside over the Khédivial School of Law at Cairo was due to the opinion that the students were, in large numbers, friendly to the Nationalist agitation, and had signed the recent petitiou for the pardon of the Denishwai prisoners. Sir E. Grey.-The answer is in the negativa Mr, MacNeill asked if the right hon. gentle- man was awaré that in the semi-native Press, which was under British control ("Oh"), the statement was made which appeared in his question. Sir E. Grey said he was not aware that it was under British control. Mr. MacNeill said the right hon. gentleman was the only member of tho House who was not aware of it ("Oh.")

div.head: ALEXANDRIA FIRE BRIGADE
div.p: The firp brigade had two calls on Wednes- day. At 1 p.m. they wore summoned to Gabbary, where Mr. Almagia's stores were on fire, and after two hours' hard work they got the flames under. To get the steamer to the scene of the fire, however, was a very difficult work, the approach being over railway lines and huge lumps of stones. The task proved an impossible one for the horses and the engine had to be almost earned over the ground by a gang of about 200 natives. In the meanwhile Mr. Almagia's workmen had been working with excellent effect and the fire brigade immediately completed the mastery over the flames. The fire was confiued to a store of paint, oil, benzine, and building materials, which were destroyed. The damages are covered by insurance. The second call was to a kitchen in Sharia Nil at 3.40 p.m, and this fire was extinguished in twenty minutes by means of cylinders and buckets.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan is at present Touring the Greek Islands.
Ibrahim o Pasha Fouad, Minister of Justice will return on Tuesday next by the Messageries Maritimes.
Mazlouin Pasha, Lord Edward Cecil, and Miralai llnpkinson Bey have returned from Cairo to Alexandria.
Ismail Pasha Sirry, Inspector ol the new works of irrigation, will sail for Europe on the 16th inst.
the 16th inst. M. Hahn von Hahnenheim, Austro-Hungarian Consul at Cairo, will leave to morrow for Europe by the Austrian Lloyd.
Dr. Ibrahim Bey Lebib, sanitary inspector of Mipieb, is retiring on pension.

At St. Peter de Merton Church, Bedford, on July 81st the marriage was solemnised between Mr. Robert Delaney, of the Egyptian Civil Service, son of the late Mr. William Delaney, of Liverpool, and Miss Minnie Ephgrave, eldest daughter of Mr. Edward Ephgrave of Bedford, formerly of Darjeeling, India.
Mr. J. Gooding, barrister-at-law, oaks us to state that he is returning to Alexandria, to continue his professional work at .No. 6 Cleopatra Street.

div.head: TRADE OF ALEXANDRIA
div.p: CONSULAR REPORT FOR 1906

Among Mediterranean ports Alexandria ranks with.Naples and Algiers after Marseilles, and Genoa. In the oourse of the last 16 years the tonnage of shipping, keeping pace with the development ot commerce, has been doubled. The total tonnage of ships out and home fn 1900 was 4,700,000; in 1906 it wm 7,800,000 tons. In 1906 the ever-increasing activity of the port had so far outstripped the accommodation that provision for considerable extensions and improvements in the general facilities for na- vigation and in harbour accommodation and apparatus was deemed imperative. The work of improvement is advancing. By June next year a new pass will be open. At present the largest commercial steamers might enter the port in safety when not exceeding 28 feet in draught, but only in perfectly smooth water, and' they would in any case run the risk of being definitely detained in the port by bad weather. Tim new pass will not only allow the largest commercial steamers safely in .aud out iu. all weathers, bu t will provido, in conjnotion with the existing pass, an alternative entrance and egress should either be blocked. The work has involved much labour. Two hopper barges, a dredger, and a tug were last year supplied . for this entreprise by a British 6rm a to**! 0084 °* about 60,000 L E. The outer harbour is to be enclosed at a cost of 120,000 LE. by prolonging the great break- water and by throwing out. a breakwater from the new cattle port quay. Good progress has already been made In this work. Three new timber quays for six ships will be finished by March, 1908. The constuotion of these quays is essential in view of the constantly increasing amount of timber imported. The value of the timber imported in 1895 was 496,000 L.E ; in 1905, 1,329,249 LE. Four of the eight berths to be available at the new coal quays arc finished, a fifth will be ready next August, the remainder by January 1, 1909. The construction of these quays is likewise essential in view of the present con- gestion of the port 615,000 tons of coal were imported in 1895, 1,132,635 tons in 1905, in the past year 1,409,754 tons. Two of four now berths nnder construction at the arsenal quay will be handed over by the engineer on January 1 next, the remaining two by June 1, 1908. The construction in the course off lost year of some 8,000 square metres of new sheds and two-stoned warehouses for the customs ad- ministration has done muo|i to lessen congestion and delay. Moreover, the abridgment of enstoms formalities and the imposition of de- murrage dues on goods left ou the quays in charge of the owners, as provided by a Quay Decree of January, 1905, are further sources of relief. It may be anticipated that the commer- cial courts will be called upon to decide A large number of demurrage cases worthy of the atten- tion of shipowners. The constant increase, and promise of increase, in the trade of Alexandria calls for a corresponding increase in the means of communication with -the interior. Since the removal of lock dues be- tween Alexandria and Cairo the Mahmoudieh Canal has been a profitable means of transport, especially for cotton, coal, timber, cement, and building materials. Recently,. however, it lias proved unequal to the increasing task imposed, and considerable congestion has ensued, so that the journey to Cairo, which should be com- pleted in four to five days, has been known to last five weeks. With a view to relieving the lower and busiest reaches of tho canal a scheme is at present nnder consideration for adding a new branch to connect Gabbari and Nonzha

div.head: A CRUESOME DISCOVERY.
div.p: A gruesome discovery was made by a workman yesterday in a well on the site of the new German hospital. Descending the well to find out the possibilities of obtaining water therefrom, he was almost overcome by a foul smell rising from its bottom, and he then saw the remains of a man's body, all the limbs of which were drawn up and the head hanging over the skeleton legs. The services of the fire- brigade were requisitioned and a man was sent down, protected by an oxygen helmet, to bring up the body, which proved to he that of a police g Kaffir who had been missing for three months. It is believed that the man, not being aware of the position of the well, fell down it on the first night of his boat. The question for the authorities to answer is, however, why was the well uncov eredt The man's death must have been instantaneous as-the depth of the well is nearly 50 feet, and his neck -must have been broken by the fall.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH
div.p: It is reported from Constantinop'e that immediately after the gala dinner at the Yildiz Palace given in honour of the Rouma- nian mission, the Sultan had a fresh attack of his illness and fainted. The imperial court was very upset and at the express desire of the 8nltan given just before his swoon the Princes Rechad and Youiwouf Eueddine were summoned to the Palace, and remained there for some time. The Sultan's attack lasted one hour. '

div.head: MINERAL WATERS.
div.p: We remind our readers that Spathis' celebrated minerals are the best in Egypt [ADVT]

div.head:
SIR. EDWARD GREY ON EGYPT
THE NEED FOR BRITISH SUPERVISION
div.p: In the debate on the Foreign Office Vote in the House of Commons, last Thursday, Sir Edward Grey, Secretary of State for Foreign Affaire, made an important statement on the situation in Egypt Dealing first of all with the Denishwai incident, which had been mentionod by Mr. H. Law, Sir Edward said : Now I pass to the Bpeeoh of the hon-raember for Donegal, who referred again to a matter which has been dealt with before in the House, and which I havo never admitted to be other- wise than a very grave one. I have really nothing to add to what I said the other evening as to the Denishawi sentences. I take no exception to the tone in which the hon. member opposite referred to it I have never dealt with itibutaa amostseriousinoident. I do not know that I can do better than quote the opinion of Lord Cromer-not the opinion which was presented in the White paper, before he had seen the evidence, but the opinion in his annual report of this year. He said:-"In the first place, although I have never entertained the least doubt as regards both the necessity of taking-proper and effective measures to punish the attack on the British officers, or the justice of the decisions at which the Court which tried the prisoners arrived, I do not conceal from myself that the episode was calculated to leave on the mind of those who were imperfectly acquainted with Egyptian tration of tho country has been conduoted. This in itself is very muoh to be regretted." That is one of tho things which I shall always fool about the Denishawi incident, that there is that tendency that it aliould be taken as typical ol what happened under British administration, whereas, on the other hand, it is most excep- tional. (Cheers.) The circumstances of the time were exceptional, and the whole circum- stances of the attaok were exceptional. With regard to the consideration of the sentences, the very long sentences which still reitisin, I did not make any actual promise the other evening, because I waa anxious tliat considerations of clemency should go to the Egyptian Government itself, for after all if clemency is to produce a good effect in Egypt it should be put to the credit of the Egyptian Government, on which the primary responsibility of administration rests. (Chéers.) But I hope the hon. member opposite and other hon. members realized from the tone of what I said tliat, although I made no actual promise, I said nothing that would preclude the prospect of the revision of those sentencee. Though it may be too early to revise those sentences, it has always seemed to me from the beginning that those sentences of very long terms of imprisonment passed on considerable numbers of people must have been passed at a time when it was thought neoessary, owing to the state of feeling in Egypt, to make a very severe example, and that when that state of things has passed away and the act of clemency is no lotiger likely to be mistaken as an act of weakness, when the feeling of Egypt is calm and favourable, then an act of clemency might he in accord not only with justice but good policy. (Hoar, hear.) One further point. The hon. member opposite criticized my action at a particular time when I asked that the question should not be discussed in the House. I think he said that my accents were those of panic and terror. I am generally told that my accents are too little dramatic. (Laughter.) But, whether that be so or not, I would point to this, tliat the only time I made an appeal was when we had not the evidence and no real in- formation before us. WKat I urged at that particular moment was that before you have the evidence, and while you have nothing but the actual fact of the sentences before you, at onoc to rush to the conclusion and to announce that the highest judicial authorities in Egypt were wrong most undermine the whole sourte of authority in Egypt But since the evidence has been before the House I have never deprecated discussion nor sought to avoid it Mr. Mac Neill asked why, when they on tliat side implored thé right hon. gentleman to get a telegraphic account of the evidence, he did not do so. Sir E. Grey. - It is impossible to retry a seriouR case by telegram. Mr. Mac Neill said the right bon. gentle- man misunderstood him. He had asked tliat an account should be furnished to the House by telegraph instead of by despatch. Sir E. Grey.-I did' not withhold from the House any information, and, as I have said, after the information was once available I never deprecated a grave incident of this kind being discussed in the Honse of Commons, or re- presented it as one that ought to have been passed without comment
EDUCATION IN EGYPT

I pass to more general questions connected with Egyptian government which bave been raised. TTie speech of the member for Brentford was devoted to thoee subjects of Egyptian government which quite rightly ought to occupy the attention of the House from the point of view of high policy. There IB the question of education I am always against the Home Government attempting to interfere in was that every year in drawing upthe Egyptian Budget there- should be some choice made, corresponding to-the means at the disposal of the Egyptian Government, As.to what reforms should Tie actually prosecuted^ that particular year. This was one of the great merit* of!Lord Cromer's Administration. ; He ensured that when money was available for. reforms in Egypt it was not frittered away from *aat off cone"n(ra- tion, by choosing something special "very ryear to.be assisted, so that eomeptPOglMi was inhde every year with one reform or. another. Dr. Rutherford.-Will, theright boa.-gentle- man bring pressure to ibearonthe Egyptian Government to provide funds for this iUniver- sity which is so essential ? ! ,i Sir E. Orey.T-My ; meaning - is that you cannot promise to provide funds -for one particular toing until you hare considered whether other things may not be more prêtaing. One must leave it tpthe Egyptian Go refissent to decide - which reform'shall,-bo taken ap in a particular year. Although the partie alar referai must be left to the Egyptian GnviWnnfesd,' the policy of spending as much as pMaiUaévury year in improving the condition of the conntry is a policy-which will be ceoeiatently followed, and the subject of education is one which is "recognized as one of those whicharemoekimpor- tant to the progress and welfare of the conatry. With regard tothe teachingof Arabia there ia no disposition on the partoftbe Egyptiad Govern- ment to' oust the teaching of that-langaage, but the teaching of English, Preoah, dr some other European language does form " large part of education, because there is a very large demand for it, and itwas found; that schools which do not provide opportunities of learning European languages were schools to wMch parents did not care to send their children. But the teaching of Arabic is a matter Which will never be treated with neglect by -the Egyptian Government. When, however, you come to the higher standards, one of the difficulties about teaching Arabic i'b not merely that the text-books do not exist, but that so much of higher commercial or scientific educa- tion nowadays consists of special knowledge for which there are no Arabia terms. It is, therefore, extremely difficult to give that instruction as efficiently in Arabic as in some European language.

div.head: SELF GOVERNMENT
div.p: The progress of municipal government id Egypt will continue, but I' cannot htinéetly say that I think Egypt is in a position in which we can realise the ideal of represen- tative self-government to the extent which the member for Braatfotd arivaaatm. I think I have heard it said that no nation is cap- able of governing itself. There *o is some- thing else to be inferred from the hon. mem- ber>^Spoech -that, though we are not cap al^o of governing another nation, we are capable witliin a generation of teaching any nation in the world those arts of self-gov- ernment ^rbioh it has taken us several cèn tunes to Iëarn. I do not wish to discourage the ideals Lord Cromer has always put forward in his reports (hat. efforts . should be constantly devoted toward. training Egyp- tian officials to take a larger part in the government of their couat^, towards the development of public spirit, ,and the qualification of Egyptians for taking part in their own home government. But the. art of government is one of the things which It takes longest to teach. You can teach almost every form of knowledge, but the art of government if something .'you canrot teach. If you- go too fast to estab- lish a country on a *ell,-gojreroing footing before the people have really acquired the neéèasary habite of. mind and Untight, before they art aocustompd to feel that in- dependence which enable.^them to protect their own lntortots quder tolfgevenwqpnk you " ' it of

div.head: SELF GOVERNMENT Cont'd
div.p: oppression, and injustice which was the only form of gorerament Egypt formerly knew. (Cheer".) Dr. Rutherford asked if the right hon.gentle- man would .press on the Egyptian Government that they would give the institutions founded by Lord Dufferin the opportunity of doing good honest work f Sir B. Grey.-The hon. member means the Legislative Council. He will find in Lord Cromer's reports that the Legislative 'Council has not been regarded with contempt In what I have said I do not wish to discoorege the ideal of self-government I should be sorry if I have given that impression tb the House ; what I wanted to do was simply to press on the House & that tho hon. member for Brentford had urged that the policy of ^elf- government should proceed with far greater speed than is either safe or possible. But in doing so I do not wish to discourage the ulti- mate ideal of developing the habits of self- government in the people.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: La tenue du marché n'a pas sensiblement différé de oe qu'elle a été pendant les trois séanoea dé la semaine qui l'ont précédée, c'est- à-dire que la cote a bien gagné une nouvelle avance mais que les affaires sont restées clairse- mées et peu importantes dans leur ensemble. La fermeté de notre plaoe n'en est pas moins remarquable en présence de la baisse à Londres des valeurs égyptiennes, de l'élévation du taux d'escompte à 4% et de la dépêche arrivée oe matin d'Amérique d'après laquelle on aurait enregistré hier à New-York la plus forte baisse des valeurs qui se soit produite depuis le krach du mois de mars. Un peu plus faible et délaissée, l'Agricole s'inscrit fi 8 1/8. Moins échangée encore, mais en demande, la National Bank s'avance de 20 1/4 vendeurs fi 20 1/4 acheteurs. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Markets haus- sent pareillement de 27/6 fi 27/9, la Sait and Soda de 18/à à 18/6, la Cassa di Sconto do 40 à 42, la Delta Imnd de 1 15/16 à 2 1/32, l'Or dinary Khédivial Mail de 21/6 fi 21/9, los Estâtes de 3/4 à 27/82, les Cotton Ginners de 1 1/4 à 1 5/16, l'Unitedde 8/8 fi 18/82 l'action et de 2 1/4 4 2 3/8 la part de fondateur, les Ritx de 11/16 à 23/82, et les Cotton Mills do 2 fi 2/6. 8ur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de châti- ments à signaler. o , 11 n'est question depuis quelques jours que du règlement des transactions en o Bourse & Banking (Arditi) dont Je cours actuel sur la cote officielle est représenté par un point d'in- terrogation. Le tableau est couvert d'avis réitérés du comité invitant tout le monde à régler ses différences. Les uns par complaisance, d'autres à cause de l'insignifianoe de leurs in- térêts enjeu, ont obtempéré aux invitations du comité.Mais les principaux intéressés continuent fi faire la sourde oreille, d'autant plus que pour toucher leu ré différences, les courtiers doivent signerune formule où il est dit "Pour solde...' etc.",oe qui signifie probablement qu'en signant une telle formuleilsrenonoentà tou te réclamât ion ultériqure.D'autre part, la livraison des titres a bien-oommenoé, mais!fi encore il faut signer une formule contenant des restrictions au bon plaisir de l'aasociatiou. En outre.il faut signer en pré- sence d'un témoin et celui-ci doit également apposer son parafe. Ouf I

Les Estates sont fermes fi 0 3/4 tandis que leur part tombe fi 8 3/4. La Sait and Soda jsfplus active à 17/6. o * * NOUH détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, en date du 3 Août, les passages suivants : "Bien qu'il soit procédé depuis quelque temps fi de très importants achats pour le compte des fonds d'amortissement, le Conso lidé continue fi baisser sans que l'on puisse prévoir où s'arrêtera sa chûte, devant la ten- dance grandissante des capitalistes fi débisser les fonds d'Etat pour des valeurs fi revenus plus élevés et tout aussi sûres. "Il a même atteint, il y a quelques jours, 82 5/8, le plus bas oours coté depuis 1848, pour se relever légèrbtnent après les déebra- tions optimistes du chanoelier de l'Echiquier et aussi fi b'suite des efforts des courtiers du gouvernement Les autres valeurs britanniques partagent le sort du Consolidé. "Pour les valeurs égyptiennes, b tendance continue k être excellente, et, quoiquo les af- faires ne soient pas nombreuses, elles sont cependant pour la plupart en reprise. "C'est ainsi que b National Bank a avancé aujourd'hui à 19 3/4 apr-'s avoir changé de mains k une fraction au-dessus de 20. "L'Agricole a ou des transactions jusqu'à 8 1/4. On note aussi une bonne demande sur les autres valeurs. "Quant au marché monétaire, les conditions iw^se modifient pas, ot l'on ne songe pas à un abaissement du taux do l'esoompte pour le moment, l'exode du métal jaune ne paraissant pas devoir s'arrêter et les prévisions des besoins monétaires intenses do l'automne étant pen faits pour améliorer le marché. 11 importe ce pendant de noter que le dernier bilan de la Banque d'Angleterre accuse une augmentation notable de son encaisse, et l'on peut espérer que pour une période osier, longue l'argent à court terme sera encore bon marché. "Quoiqu'il en soit, on s'attend pour les jours prochains fi un marché terne avec recrudes- cence dévissé. o # o A l'Assemblée do la Cor|>oration des agents de change, qui aura lieu aujourd'hui, pour discuter les conditions do rétablissement du marché fi terme, le Comité aurait l'intention de proposer que seules les valeurs cotées offi- ciellement efentièrement libérées soient ad- mises à faire l'objet d'opérations fi terme. Les liquidations se feraient de quinzaine en quinzaine par l'entremise d'une "Chambre de compensation" à laquelle chaque agence re mettrait le lendemain des jours de liquidation ou de compensation un état nominatif de ses débita et de ses crédits envers ses oollègnes, et le surlendemain le montent par lui éventuel lemeut dû. * o o Pour faire suite à notre information d'hier sur b résiliation de la vente du Savoy Hotel, nous donnons pour ce qu'elle vaut, la rumeur suivante : Comme conséquence de l'abandon de l'achat du Savoy Hotel par les Estates, b Compagnie Nungovich serait décidée à conti- nuer l'exploitation dudit Les pourparlers qu'elle avait engagés avec le gouvernement pour acquérir un emplacement entroie Ghe- tireh Palace et la tête du futur Pont de Boulac et où elle avait l'intention de construire un Hûtel du même nom, n'ayant pas abouti.

div.head:
COSMOPOLITAN MR. PICKWICK
A UNIQUE EXHIBITION
div.p: (FROM OUR LONDON CORRESPONDENT)

August 2. This is the season of exhibitions, but for the student of literature nothing more interesting has been conceived than tho Pickwick Exhibi- tion, which is being held at the New Dudley Gallery, Piccadilly, to commemorate the 70th. anniversary of the completion of "The Pick- wick Paliers". The admirers of Pickwick know no limita of class or nationality. They are to be found tho world over among rich and poor, young and old. Tho influence of Pickwiok grows with tho pasaage of years, and at tho present day the work commands a larger aale than at any period in its history. As Mr. Percy Fitzgerald says, in an interesting article in the admirable catalogue of the pxhibition, compiled by Mr. B.W. Mat*, and Mr. J.W.T. Ley, Hon. General Secretary of tho Dickens Fellowship, "Pickwick is everything and contains ev^rytliing-liumorous as well as pa- thetic, a book of travels, a biography, a chron- icle of manners and customs, a tragedy, a comedy and obstreperous farce all in one, and a personal histoiy of the author himself." It is "safe to say that no other single work has producer I such an enor- mous number of hooks and commentaries, parodies and illustrations. The Dic- kens Fellowship have gathered together a collection of these, the extent ami variety of which are astonishing. They comprise editions printed in the languages of most nations, from tho first English edition pub- lished in 1887 to the latest cheap edi- tions. An interesting feature are the Ame- rican editions. Dickens suffered much at the hands of American publishing pirates and there are in the. exhibition copies of eleven editions, dating from 1887, which appeared prior to the first authorised edi- tion, which was issued in 1807. Mr. Fitzgerald points out a very humor- ous feature in connection with the illus- tration in a German edition. All tho cha- racters are drawn to represent Germans and all the backgrounds show German furniture and decorations. 'iPickwick" lias been parodied and plagar ised to an unlimited extant. The rarest of these publications is "The Penny Pickwick : The most-humoroiiM notes of the Pickwickian Club," edited by "Bos". This was publj- shed in 1837, aiid is made up from a set of the original. Penny Numbers, with the wood-cut title pages and two of the month- ly Coloured Pictorikl Wrappers bound in. Then we have "Pickwick Married" "Pick- wick in America," "Pickwick Abroad; or the Tour in France," "Pickwick in IndiA." "Sam Weller's Pickwick Jest Book," etc. There is also a rare collection of Pickwick pictures which alone would ensure rhe suc- cess of the exhibition, and the portraits of the master at various periods of his life will be noted with much interest. Charles Dickens appealed to the biographer in a special manner, and there are exhibited no less than ' 35 biographies anil sketches of his career. o The exhibition will lie o|ieii until Au- gust 28th.

div.head: A HANDBOOK OF EGYPTIAN RELIGION
div.p: This is a translation of Die igyptuobe Religion,' published two yean ago aa one & the manuals or guide-books of the Berlin Im penal Museums. Some fifteen years ago Prof. Erman, on the occasion of Egyptology being formally admitted as a science into the Royal Prussian Academy, announced in his introductory ora- tion that the epoch of grwH discoveries in Egypt waacloeed, and.thatEgy^toIogista would henceforth do well to devote themselves to the patient study of the ancient Egyptian lan- guage, aayB the "Atbenæum." Such prophecies are by no means rare among what we may call, without using the word in any offensive sense, the pedantioally-minded, but have a way of being falsified by events. In this oase, the glanoe into fntority of the Berlin Professor of Egyptology was almost immediately followed by the announcement of the extraordinary dis- coveries of M.de Morgan at Negadah and of M. Amélinaau ât Abydoa, which triumphantly vindicated the general accuracy of Manetho's history, and convinced ns ot the actual ex- istence of those kingB of the early dynasties' whom we had come to regard in the same light as Brut the son of Æneas, or King Bladnd of Bath. But the 'causa causons' of the prophecy may perhaps be found in the fact that its ut- terer had already pot forth a grammar in which he had elaborated certain propositions, since somewhat modified. To take them in their latest form, they may be reduced to the follow- ing:- 1. That Egyptian is a Semitic language, having Arabia as its country of origin. 2. That, like Hebrew, it was written from the earliest times without vowels. 3. That its. grammar must follow the forms of other Semitic tongues, such as Hebrew and Arabic. These propositions, which are by no means inherently absurd, have been rejected in turn by all the leading Egyptologists in Europe. M. Maspero, at ouoe the official head of Egypto- logy and the most brilliant exponent of Egyp- tian antiquity that the world has yet seen, has repeatedly exposed, with as much courtesy as point, the many fallacies comprised iu them. Karl Piehl, the veteran professor of Upsala, whose erudition in Egyptian matters was pro- found, never ceased, till his death three years ago, to thunder against them. M. Victor Loret, a former Director of the Service des Antiquités and the author of what is still the best introduction to the Egyptian language, bns always combated the German innovations, and has laboured to show that the hieroglyphs expressed vocalic as well as consonantal sounda Dr. Naville, the favourite pupil ofLepsius, and i whose services to the literature of the subject have been as valuable as those which he lias rendered to archæology by his twenty- years of exploration in Egypt, has not only rejected the German propositions in Into, Qut bos also advanced the counter-.theory that the most ancient Egyptian texts known to us, so far from exhibiting the peculiarities of Semitic grammar, show that the language in which they wore written had not yet attained to the use of grammatical forms at all. Nor lias the German theory been much better received in England. Renouf, the successor of Birch at the British Museum and an early master of com liorative philology, would have none of it ; and since his day the Museum authorities have contented themselves with ignoring the German innovations, without troubling themselves to lemonstrate actively against them. Tluit, notwithstanding this consensus of learned opinion, the theories of the Berlin School should continue to live and flourish, is groat measure due to the skilful, tactics pursued by their promulgators. Profiting, pcrbnps, by the example of certain theologians they have, instead of arguing in favour of the truth of their propositions, assumed that they were true, and have acted as if their truth neeeded no further demonstration. For fifteen years they have not ceased to pour forth grammars, glossaries, and chreeto mathies founded upon tlie supposed Somitic character of^tbe Egyptian language ; they have adopted as trade-mark a system of trans- literation so uncouth that it cannot be repro- duced without special types, so ill suited to its purpose that it conveys to tho reader no idea of the sound of the words transliterated, and ao inefficient that they are obliged to use another in works .addressed to the general public ; and they have arranged tliat the grtat dictionary orthesaurus of the Egyptian tongue, which the liberality of the German Emperot and the co-operation ot Egyptologists through- out the world have made possible, shall be constructed in accordance with their own theories. By these acts they have contrived to lead astray some of onr own countrymon, and in particular the painstaking scholar who has made himself responsible for tlie intro- duction of, the present work to tho English public, and who, both in his former capacity as assistant to Prof. Petrie at University College, London, and in his present one as Reader in Egyptology at Oxford, lias had peculiar opportunities of impressing the Ger- man views on the risjng generation. Yet one fact alone must have often given pause to those who felt themselves attracted by the "acien tifio". form in which the German theories are clothed. Magnificent aa baa been the grammatical equipment on the adherent* of the Berlin School, it has proved utterly inade quate to the purpose for which the grammar of a dead language is generally supposed to be designed-that is to say, for making intel- ligible to modern ears .the documents written in it While other European scholars ImM continued to study and translate Egyptian texts in abundance ; while M. Maspero has given to tlie world the Pyramid Texts which are the oldest, and probably the most difficult, of Egyptian writings; while Renouf and Dr. Naville have reconstructed the text, and pub- lished a translation, of The Book of the Dead' ; and while Dr. Budge has found time to torn into English the other funerary texte known as ''rhe Book of That which is in Hades' and The Book of Gates,' Dr. Erman and his pupils have apparently exhausted their ingenuity in discussing paradigms, pseudo-participles, and the grammatical machinery which we are be- ginning to get rip of in the study of the dearie languages. Bat all this time they have done little to make ns familiar with the literature of the Egyptians, and the Wes tear Papyrus, a of aagio tales, ia almost the only text of which they have published a The obvions inference is that the have forged with sooh pains is in- sufficient for its purpose, and that, like the bayonets said to be "made in Germany," with certain English regiments were once armed, it fails when it u put to real use. With theee facts in view, we are ablo to appreciate at their true value many of the statements made ex cathedra in the volumo before us. In the very first page Prof. Erman tells us that "the valley of the Lower Nile" was originally inhabited by a people of African race, and that when ''the needy Bedouins of the Arabian peninsula seized the country. . . . the Egyptians adopted their language, but not their civilization." But the facts are really tlie other way. There is some evidence that in the time of the king generally called Narmer- whom the Berlin School, through their spokes- man Dr. Sethe, would make the second king of the First, and Dr. Naville and M. Georges Foucart the first king of the Secdnd Dynasty-Egypt was inhabited by an African race, and invaded by conquerors possessing an alien civiliiation. But this civilization-shown by the use of bricks for building, of the cylin- der-seal and brick stamp, and, more doubtfully, of pictorial writing- had ita prototype among not the Semitic, but the Sumerian inhabitants of Babylonia, and was far superior to anything likely to be found among "needy" nomads. As for the language, if Prof. Erman's statement were well founded, wo should expeot to find the Semitic element in Egyptian more strongly marked the nearer we get to the conqueet ; whereas in the earliest documents it is almost non-existent, and it does not become really prominent nntil the time of the Middle King- dom, which the author is obliged, therefore, to proclaim as tlie period during which the Egyp- tian language attained its greatest purity, but which is tlie very time when the Egyptians were in actual and close contact with the Semitic nations. As for the non-acceptance of tlie conqueror's civilization by the Egyptians, those who compare the monuments ol the First Dynasty with those of, say, the Eighteenth will find tlie progress of Egyptian art one un- checked degradation from a good model, such as has been seen at Benin and other places where the black races have adopted the con- ventions of their European teachers. In these matters, therefore, Prof. Erman has simply tumed tlie facts upside down to suit his own theories. (To be continued) '

div.p: Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
5 fr. et 2 fr. 50

div.head: Sudan Governent
div.p: NOTICE

Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are recommended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labourers in the presence of an official or other reliable witness.
